questions.text: Dr. Anand, a distinguished orthopedic surgeon, has been invited to give expert testimony in a complicated case where a fellow surgeon is accused of negligence during a hip arthroplasty. In the course of preparing for his deposition, Dr. Anand revisits legal terminologies pertinent to his testimony, particularly concerning witness compensation known as 'conduct money'. Which of the following assertions about 'conduct money' is inaccurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is paid by the court.

 

Option D:

 

'Conduct money' is the term used for funds provided to a witness to cover their costs associated with appearing in court, such as travel and time. The responsibility for this payment rests with the party who has summoned the witness. The rationale behind 'conduct money' is to ensure that the witness does not incur out-of-pocket expenses as a result of assisting the court.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Conduct money is paid to witness in civil cases, while serving summons.

 

Options B. It is customarily dispensed at the time of summons service to ensure the witness can attend the court proceedings without personal expense.

 

Options C. While a judge may have input on the amount, it is often governed by legal statutes or regulations rather than being left solely to judicial discretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conduct money:

 

  • It is the fee offered or paid to a witness in civil cases, at the time of serving the summons to meet the expenses for attending the Court.

  • If the witness thinks that the amount is less according to his status, then he can ask the judge in the Court for an additional amount before giving evidence in the court. However, the final amount is decided by the Judge.

  • But in criminal cases no money is paid at the time of serving the summons. The witness must attend the Court in the interest of justice. The government usually pays Travel Allowance to attend the court, but this is not called conduct money.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. p9

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was detained in police custody is found dead in his cell under unclear circumstances. The legal system mandates an inquest to ascertain the cause of death and investigate any wrongdoing. According to section 176 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), which official is tasked with the investigation of deaths occurring under such legal custody?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Judicial magistrate

 

Option C:

 

Custodial death (death in judicial custody) is the only condition where inquest is mandatory to be done only by a Judicial Magistrate. Police custody is a kind of judicial custody.

 

Types of inquest are as follows:

 

  1. Police Inquest: Done under section 174 CrPc. It is the most common inquest in India. Minimum rank of police officer who can conduct the inquest is Head constable

  2. Magistrate Inquest: Done under section 176 CrPc. It is done in few conditions in India. It is of further two types:

  3. Executive Magistrate: It conducts inquest in two cases: Dowry death & Exhumation.

  4. Judicial Magistrate - Done in Custodial Deaths (custody of state. E.g., police custody, jail, rehabilitation, psychiatric hospital etc)

  5. Coroner’s inquest: Not done in India. It is done in UK. Here the inquest is done by judicial officers.

  6. Medical examiner system: Not done in India. It is done in USA. Here the inquest is done by doctors. It is the best inquest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The executive magistrate is responsible for inquests in two conditions:

 

  • Dowry death (Death within 7 years of marriage, and death was unnatural and related to dowry) - 304B IPC- Executive magistrate

  • Exhumation – digging out of buried bodies. Executive magistrate

 

Option B. The jail superintendent manages the administrative functions of the prison but does not conduct legal inquests into custodial deaths.

 

Option D. The sub-inspector may be involved in the preliminary response but is not authorized to conduct the official inquest into a custodial death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, inquests are classified as Police Inquests, conducted by police officers of at least Head Constable Rank, and Magistrate Inquests, divided into Executive Magistrate Inquests for dowry deaths and exhumation, and Judicial Magistrate Inquests for custodial deaths.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 6-7

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. The case has drawn significant media attention, and there is pressure on authorities to conduct a thorough investigation. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done in India for such cases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Police Inquest

 

INQUEST: An inquest is an inquiry or investigation into the cause of death.

 

Types of inquest In India:

 

  1. Police Inquest: Done under section 174 CrPc. It is the most common inquest in India. Minimum rank of police officer who can conduct the inquest is Head constable.

  2. Magistrate Inquest: Done under section 176 CrPc. It is done in few conditions in India. It is of further two types:

  3. Executive Magistrate: It conducts inquest in two cases:

    • Dowry death (Death within 7 years of marriage, and death  was unnatural and related to dowry)

    • Exhumation – digging out of buried bodies.

  4. Judicial Magistrate - Done in Custodial Deaths (custody of state. E.g., police custody, jail, rehabilitation, psychiatric hospital etc)

 

The case in question does not fulfill any of the conditions of magistrate inquest, so it will be done by the police.

 

Explanation:

 

Options B. Magistrate Inquest is done in few conditions like Dowry death, exhumation, and custodial deaths.

 

Options C. Coroner inquest - Not done in India. It is done in the UK. Here the inquest is done by judicial officers.

 

Options D. Medical examiner’s inquest - Not done in India. It is done in the USA. Here the inquest is done by doctors. It is the best inquest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the commonest inquest is police inquest. Other than police inquest the other inquest is magistrate inquest which is done in few conditions like Dowry death, exhumation, and custodial deaths. Coroner’s inquest and medical examiner system are not done in India.

Two social workers (at least one woman). These social workers should have either experience of 7 years in child welfare activities OR a professional degree in child psychology, psychiatry, sociology, or law.

questions.text: During a complex murder trial, the defense attorney argues that the local court overseeing the case lacks the authority to sentence their client to the death penalty, should they be found guilty. As a medical professional called to serve as an expert witness on the psychological state of the defendant, you're asked to familiarize yourself with the judicial power of sentencing in India. Which of the courts listed below is not authorized to pass a death sentence under Indian law?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magistrate court

 

Option A:

 

In India, the power to award a death sentence is vested in the High Court and Supreme Court. The Sessions/ Additional Sessions Court can also award a death sentence, but it must be confirmed by the High Court. The Magistrate courts are lower courts than sessions court and do not have the authority to award capital punishment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Additional session court can pass death sentence , but a sentence of death passed by it must be confirmed by the High Court.

 

Option C. Session court can pass death , but a sentence of death passed by it must be confirmed by the High Court.

 

Please note that “sessions” and “additional sessions” courts have the same powers, whereas “assistant sessions court” is lower than sessions court.

 

Option D. The High Court is usually located in the capital of every State and is the highest tribunal for the State. It may try any offence and pass any sentence authorized by law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indian Court System

questions.text: Dr. Khanna, a well-respected physician, was recently brought before a medical ethics committee after allegations surfaced of her having provided a falsified medical certificate to an influential patient. This has now attracted the attention of legal authorities, and she may face charges under the Indian Penal Code (IPC). If the allegations prove true, under which section of the IPC would Dr. Khanna be charged for issuing or signing a false medical certificate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) S.197

 

Option C:

 

Section 197 of the Indian Penal Code provides for the prosecution of persons who issue or sign a false certificate. It is intended to address the legal repercussions for a medical professional who issues a false certificate. The issuance of such a certificate is a violation of the trust and legal duty imposed upon the professional.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. S. 193 IPC deals with punishment for false evidence (Perjury) under oath. Punishment is imprisonment for up to 7 years.

 

Options B. S.194 IPC addresses giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure a conviction of a capital offence.

 

Options D. S.201 IPC pertains to causing the disappearance/ destruction of evidence of an offence or giving false information to screen an offender. Not collecting & preserving evidence like - clothes, vomitus etc.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with terminal cancer in the hospital makes a statement regarding his condition and the events leading up to his hospitalization. The attending physician understands that this could be a crucial piece of evidence, potentially classifiable as either a dying declaration or a dying deposition. In the context of legal proceedings, why is a dying deposition considered to carry more weight than a dying declaration?

A dying deposition differs from a dying declaration in that it is taken under oath, providing a formal and legal assertion of the truthfulness of the statement. Additionally, during a deposition, there is an opportunity for cross-examination by defense lawyers, which allows for more rigorous testing of the evidence. Finally, recording by a magistrate, adds to its credibility.

questions.text: Dr. Aarav, serving as an expert witness in a pivotal medical malpractice lawsuit, has concluded his initial testimony. As the proceedings transition to the cross-examination phase, the defense counsel gears up for an exhaustive session of questioning. In the context of legal procedure, what is the customary time allocation for the cross-examination phase in a trial?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No time limit

 

Explanation:

 

Cross-examination is a critical component of the trial process, allowing the defense attorney to question the witness presented by the prosecution. Contrary to other phases of a trial which may be time-bound, cross-examination does not have a predefined time limit. This lack of restriction is designed to ensure that the defense has a full and fair opportunity to challenge the testimony of a witness, a principle that upholds the adversarial nature of legal proceedings.

 

RECORDING EVIDENCE IN COURT

 

  1. Oath (except Person <12yrs, oath not required)

  2. Examination in chief (Direct Examination)- By lawyer who summoned the witness (Mostly public prosecutor). Only facts stated, leading questions not allowed.

  3. Cross examination – By layer of the opposite party (mostly the defense lawyer). Leading questions allowed. There is no time limit for cross examination. The lawyer tries to weaken the evidence of the witness by showing that his details are inaccurate, conflicting, contradictory, and untrustworthy.

  4. Re-examination (Re-Direct Examination)– By a lawyer who summoned a witness. If something was missed in the examination in chief, that is asked in re-examination. Leading questions not allowed. It helps to clear any doubts that may have arisen during

  5. Questions by judge / court questions – can be done any time

 

Educational Objective:

 

In legal trials, the cross-examination phase does not typically have a predefined time limit. The length of cross-examination is generally determined by the complexity of the case, the amount of evidence, and the discretion of the judge overseeing the trial. The goal is to allow ample time for the defense counsel to thoroughly question the witness to ensure a fair and comprehensive assessment of the testimony.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 14

questions.text: Dr. Ray, a forensic specialist, is in a conundrum as he receives simultaneous summons from various courts for his expert testimony - all scheduled on the same day. With the summons spread across different levels of the judiciary and case types, he needs to determine which court holds the primary claim on his attendance. Considering the hierarchy and the nature of the cases, which court should Dr. Ray prioritize for his appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Summon from the High Court in a civil case

 

Option A:

 

  • If summons received from two courts to appear on the same day:

 

1. Higher courts have priority over lower courts.

 

2. Criminal courts have priority over civil courts.

 

Please Note: Ranking of the court (higher versus lower) is more important than Criminal versus civil. If summoned to two courts on the same day, either civil or criminal, always attend the higher court first.

 

3. If the summon is from two courts of the same Rank, give priority to the summon received first.

 

Two types of summonses:

 

1. Subpoena ad testificandum: It is the usual standard Summon where the witness has to give oral evidence.

 

2. Subpoena duces tecum: Only orders the Person to bring the required documents (e.g. books, papers etc..) written in the summon. Sec. 61–69 CrPC deals with summons.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Although criminal courts usually have priority over civil courts, they would still be second to a summons from the High Court.

 

Option C. The Session Court in a civil case would be a lower priority compared to the High Court.

 

Option D. A summons from the Chief Judicial Magistrate in a civil case would not take precedence over a summons from the High Court.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In instances where simultaneous court summons are received, priority is generally given based on the hierarchy of the courts and the nature of the cases. The hierarchy of the court takes precedence over the type of case (civil vs. criminal). Therefore, a summon from a higher court, such as the High Court, should be prioritized over lower courts, regardless of whether the case is civil or criminal.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 9

questions.text: Dr. Jaya, a general practitioner, was shocked when law enforcement arrived at her clinic to place her under arrest without a warrant. As she reviews her recent actions and the potential legal ramifications, she contemplates which of her duties, if breached, would constitute a cognizable offence leading to such an immediate arrest scenario.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prescribing medication that resulted in death due to a rash and negligent act

 

Option A:

 

Death due to a rash and negligent act can lead to immediate arrest (Cognizable Offence-Section 106 BNS), as it poses a significant concern for public safety.

 

Explanation:

 

Options B. Rape is a serious Cognizable offence, but failure to report a serious crime is a non-cognizable offence (section 239 BNS).

 

Option C: Perjury is a non-cognizable offence (section 229 BNS), and, hence requires a warrant as it is not an immediate threat to public safety. Perjury means giving wilful false/fabricated evidence. BNS related to false evidence (all are non-cognizable, hence will require warrant to arrest).

 

 Option D: This is incorrect option as B is not a cognizable offence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cognizable offences are those for which a police officer has the authority to make an arrest without a warrant from the magistrate. These are usually serious offences like rape, murder, robbery, death due to negligence or rash act, etc., that may pose an immediate danger to public safety or order.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 13

questions.text: During a lecture, a senior resident explains to medical students the hierarchy of evidence in legal proceedings. When it comes to the weightage of different types of evidence in an Indian court, which one is usually prioritized by the judiciary in making decisions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral

 

Oral evidence is more important than documentary evidence, as it permits cross-examination. Documentary evidence is accepted by the Court only on oral testimony by the person concerned. Oral evidence may be direct/ indirect/ hearsay.

 

A medical opinion is subjective and subject to interpretation and further cross questioning. Hence medical opinion in injury report, postmortem report, Age report, Medicolegal certificates etc. are never admissible in court as document alone, they must be accompanied by the oral evidence of concerned Doctor.

 

Exception to oral evidence (where document alone is acceptable):

 

  1. Dying declaration

  2. Expert opinions expressed in a book

  3. Deposition of a medical witness taken in a lower court

  4. Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding

  5. Statements by persons who cannot be called as witnesses: e.g. dead, untraceable etc.

  6. Report of certain government scientific experts:

    1. Chemical Examiner

    2. Chief Controller  of  Explosives

    3. Director  of Fingerprint  Bureau

    4. Director of a Central Forensic Science Laboratory

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Circumstantial evidence is not the direct testimony of an eye witness, but has a bearing upon other fact, e.g., in case of alleged murder of A by B at certain place on a particular day and time, the circumstantial evidence would be that C saw B with a knife on that day at that place, a few minutes before the murder. Circumstantial evidence requires the Court to draw logical inferences from the information presented.

 

Options C. Documentary evidence includes all documents produced for the inspection of the Court. Documentary evidence is accepted in court only after oral testimony of the concerned person who prepared the document except in few cases (e.g. dying declaration, expert opinion expressed in a treatise, etc).

 

Options D. Hearsay is any statement made by any person about what he did not personally witness, , e.g., A gives evidence in the witness box stating that B had informed him that he had seen C committing a crime. Hearsay is generally not admissible in court because it does not allow for cross-examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral evidence includes all statements which are required to be made in court by a witness. It must be direct—it must be evidence of an eyewitness. Oral evidence is more important than documentary evidence, as it permits cross-examination.

 

Ref:- Reddy 33/e. Pg 9

questions.text: In a pediatric malpractice case, the testimony of a young patient who witnessed a critical event is pivotal. The court must decide whether the child should be required to take a formal oath before testifying. According to legal standards, below what age is a child typically not required to take an oath in court?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Below 12 years

 

Explanation:

 

In many jurisdictions, including India, this age is commonly set at below 12 years, reflecting the understanding that younger children may not grasp the concept of swearing to tell the truth in a legal sense.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Before giving evidence, a witness has to take oath which defined under 51 IPC (a child below 12 years is not required to take oath). Refusing to take oath is punishable under 178 IPC (6 months or Rs 1000 or both).

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 13

questions.text: In a mock trial as part of legal training for medical professionals, the concept of a 'hostile witness' is introduced. Dr. Lalit, a senior resident, is asked to play the role of an expert witness, and during the proceedings, a discussion arises regarding the characteristics of a hostile witness. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the nature of a hostile witness in court?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cannot be examined by same side lawyer

 

Option A:

 

A hostile witness is one who is not willing to tell the truth or is adversarial, and the court may permit the party that called the witness to ask leading questions, typically reserved for cross-examination. The idea that a witness cannot be examined by the same side lawyer is false. If a witness is declared hostile, they can indeed be examined and even cross-examined by the lawyer who called them.

 

Explanation:

 

Options B. Statement is true; a court can declare a witness hostile upon the suggestion of the prosecution lawyer, allowing them to be questioned more rigorously.

 

Options C. Statement is true; any witness, whether common or expert, can be declared hostile if they demonstrate adversarial behavior or unwillingness to tell the truth.

 

Options D. Statement is true as a hostile witness may have a motive for not being forthcoming with the truth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A hostile witness is one who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing part of the truth, or for giving completely false evidence (S.191, I.P.C.).

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 13

questions.text: As part of the courtroom procedures module, medical students are learning about the different phases of witness examination in a trial. Dr. Kaur, a legal medicine instructor, quizzes the residents to assess their understanding of when leading questions are typically permitted in court. At which stage of witness examination are leading questions generally allowed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross-examination

 

Option B:

 

  • Leading questions suggest the answer or contain the information the examiner is looking to have confirmed.

  • These types of questions are usually not permitted during the examination-in-chief when a party is questioning their own witness, as they can lead the witness towards a desired answer.

  • However, during cross-examination, when the opposing party is questioning the witness, leading questions are permitted.

  • This allows the cross-examining lawyer to test the witness's testimony and challenge their credibility or the content of their statements.

  • A leading question is one which suggests to the witness the answer desired, or which includes a material fact, and admits of a conclusive answer by a simple "Yes" or "No" (S. l41, I:E.A.).

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Examination-in-chief is the initial phase of witness testimony where leading questions are not permitted because the witness is providing their own account without being influenced by the questioning party.

 

Options C. Re-examination is conducted after cross-examination and typically does not involve leading questions, as it is a chance to clarify or rebut specific points raised during cross-examination.

 

Options D. Leading questions are not generally allowed at any stage of examination; they are specifically used during cross-examination for the purposes of challenging the witness's testimony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leading questions - It is a type of question whose answer can be given in “yes” or “No”. IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA.

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in:  1) Examination in chief 2) Re-Examination 3) Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in: 1) Cross Examination 2) Dying Deposition 3) Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 14-15

questions.text: During a seminar on the legal responsibilities of healthcare professionals, Dr. Mehta explains the significance of complying with court orders. He poses a question to the attendees to test their understanding of the legal repercussions of failing to respond to a summons from a criminal court. What section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) addresses the penalty for not attending a criminal court summons?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 174 IPC

 

Option A:

 

Section 174 of the Indian Penal Code pertains to non-attendance in obedience to an order from a public servant. If a person summoned by a court or public servant legally competent to issue such a summons fails to attend without a lawful excuse, they can be punished under this section. It is specifically designed to address the failure to respond to legal processes, such as a court summons.

 

Explanation:

 

Options B. Section 191 IPC deals with giving false or false or fabricated evidence under oath (definition).

 

Options C. Section 193 IPC is about punishment (imprisonment upto 7 years) for false or fabricated evidence under oath.

 

Options D. Section 294 IPC pertains to Exhibitionism (showing private parts/ any obscene act in public places). It is punishable with imprisonment upto 3 month or fine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Section 172, 173 and 174 IPC are all related to not attending to summon and the punishment in all of these is same (imprisonment up-to 6 months or fine of 1000 Rs or both)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is found dead in his apartment under suspicious circumstances. The police are investigating the case, and a forensic expert is examining the body. The investigation reveals signs of struggle and possible foul play. As part of the legal proceedings, the forensic expert must be aware of the legal framework governing punishments for criminal activities in India. Which of the following acts primarily guides the imposition of punishment in such criminal cases in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Indian Penal Code (IPC)

 

Option A:

 

Indian Penal Code (IPC) 1860: It is a comprehensive code that deals with substantive criminal law of India. It defines various offences and prescribes code for punishment in the court of law. In a case involving a suspicious death, such as the scenario described, the IPC would be the relevant legal document to determine the nature of the crime and the corresponding punishment.

 

Explanation:

 

Options B. Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC): (1973) It deals with procedures of investigation and the mechanism for punishment of offences against the substantive criminal law. While it is crucial for the procedural aspects of criminal investigation and trial, it does not define offenses or prescribe punishments.

 

Options C. Indian Evidence Act (IEA): (1872) This act deals with the admissibility of evidence in Indian courts. It is common to both the criminal and civil procedure. It is vital in the judicial process but does not deal with defining crimes or setting punishments.

 

Options D. Coroner's Act: This act deals with the procedures related to the investigation of deaths, particularly in cases of unexplained or suspicious deaths. However, it does not prescribe punishments for criminal activities.

 

Educational Objective:
 

While the Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the primary legal document for defining crimes and prescribing punishments, CrPC describes the inquiry processes & IEA deals with the admissibility of evidence in Indian courts.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 6

questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman was found dead in her home under suspicious circumstances. She had been married for 4 years, and her parents have filed a complaint alleging frequent dowry demands from her in-laws. In this scenario, under which legal section should the autopsy of this woman be conducted to investigate the cause of her unnatural death, especially in the context of the alleged dowry demands?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Section 176 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC)

 

Option B:

 

Section 176 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) in India is invoked for conducting an autopsy in cases of deaths that occur under suspicious conditions, especially if it's within 7 years of marriage and related to dowry demands. This section mandates a thorough inquiry into the cause of death.

 

Sec. 176 CrPC deals with inquiry by Magistrate into cause of death

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Section 174 CrPC: Police Inquest done under section 174 CrPc. It is the most common inquest in India. Minimum rank of police officer who can conduct the inquest is Head constable

 

Options C. Section 302 IPC: This section pertains to the punishment for murder, which is a post-facto application after the cause and intention of death have been established, not for the procedure of autopsy.

 

Options D. Section 304B IPC: This section deals with the offense of dowry death and its punishment. While it is relevant to the case scenario, it does not govern the procedure for conducting an autopsy.

Section 176 of CrPC is specifically invoked for conducting autopsies in cases where the death occurs under suspicious circumstances, especially within 7 years of marriage and in the context of dowry demands.

questions.text: In the investigation of a 30-year-old convict who was found deceased under unclear circumstances in a prison, the local authorities are discussing the appropriate legal procedure for the inquest. Understanding the legal framework for inquests in such cases is crucial for the forensic team. Which section of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) in India pertains to the type of inquest that should be conducted in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magistrate inquest

 

Option D:

 

Section 176 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) in India relates to the inquiry by a magistrate into the cause of death. This section is invoked in cases of death under suspicious circumstances, suicides, deaths in police custody, or in prison. A magistrate inquest is a more detailed inquiry compared to a police inquest (Section 174 CrPC) and is required in few selected conditions, like death in the jail as in this case.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Coroner inquest: Not done in India. It is done in UK. Here the inquest is done by judicial officers.

 

Options B. Summons: This option is irrelevant as it pertains to the process of calling someone to court, not to the inquest of a death.

 

Options C. Police inquest: While Section 174 CrPC deals with police inquests in cases of unnatural deaths, Section 176 CrPC specifically refers to magistrate inquests, which are conducted under few selected circumstances and are more detailed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The magistrate inquest under Section 176 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which is employed in cases requiring detailed investigation due to the suspicious nature of the death.

 

Indication - only in three conditions (under section 176 Crpc):

 

  1. Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage

  2. Exhumation- By Executive Magistrate

  3. Custodial Deaths- By Judicial Magistrate

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 7

questions.text: A 40-year-old man convicted of a serious crime in a lower court decides to appeal the judgment. His legal counsel is advising him on the appropriate court to approach for appealing the judgment. In the Indian judicial system, which of the following courts serves primarily as a Court of Appeal in such cases?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Court

 

Option D:

 

The High Court stands as a Court of Appeal in the Indian judicial system. It hears appeals from the decisions of the lower courts (like Sessions and Magistrate courts). The High Court has the authority to overturn or modify decisions made by these lower courts.

 

Some important Pointers –

 

  • High Court is usually located in the capital of every State and is the highest court in the state.

  • Judges in a High Court are appointed by the President of India in consultation with the Chief Justice of India and the Governor of the State.

  • It deals with appeals from lower courts and writ petitions in terms of Article 226 of the Constitution.

  • It may try any offence and pass any sentence authorized by law (Sec. 28 CrPC).

  • Supreme Court and High Courts act as Courts of appeal only in criminal cases, and do not hold trial prima facie.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sessions court - Sessions Court is usually located at the district headquarters and is also known as District Session Court, and presided over by a District and Sessions Judge, who is known as a District Judge when he presides over a civil case, and a Sessions Judge when he presides over a criminal case. Appointment of district Judge is done either by the state Government in consultation with the High Court or by way of elevation of Judges from courts subordinate to district courts. While It can try cases which have been committed to it by a Magistrate, it also tries cases directly. So High court is a better answer; it is primarily a court of appeal. It can pass any sentence authorized by law including death sentence which is subject to confirmation by the High Court (Sec. 28 CrPC).

 

Option B. Magistrate’s court: Handles preliminary hearings and smaller civil and criminal cases, not appeals from higher courts. These are of three types: Chief Judicial Magistrate, First Class Judicial Magistrate and Second-Class Judicial Magistrate. Powers of Magistrate court is given in Sec. 29 CrPC. Higher courts can enhance the sentence awarded by it.

 

Option C. Coroner’s court: Deals with inquests into sudden or unexplained deaths and does not function as a Court of Appeal. Not followed in India. No power to impose fine/ punish.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Appellate Vs Trial Courts

 

  1. 1. Supreme court and High Court: Mainly appellate court, though sometimes they can act as trial court also.

  2. 2. Sessions court, Assistant session court/ CJM: Mainly trial court, though sometimes they can act as appellate court also.

  3. 3. First class judicial magistrate / 2nd class judicial magistrate: Only trial courts, no appeal

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 7

questions.text: In the context of the Indian judicial system, the appointment of judges at various levels is a critical aspect of maintaining the integrity of the judiciary. Who is responsible for appointing a First-Class Judicial Magistrate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chief Justice of High Court

 

In metropolitan cities with more than 1 million population, the Chief Judicial Magistrate and first-class Judicial Magistrate are designated as Chief Metropolitan Magistrate and Metropolitan Magistrate respectively (S.8, 17, 18 and 19 CrPC).

 

The High Court appoints the Judicial Magistrate of first class to the Chief Judicial Magistrate (Sec. 12 CrPC). Powers of Magistrate court is given in Sec. 29 CrPC. Higher court can enhance the sentence awarded by it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Governor: In the Indian judicial system, the Governor does play a role in appointing higher judiciary members, such as judges of the High Court, in consultation with the Chief Justice of India and the Chief Justice of the High Court.

 

Option C. Chief Minister of the State: The Chief Minister, as the head of the state government, does not have a role in the appointment of judicial officers. The separation of powers doctrine in the Indian Constitution keeps the judiciary independent from the executive branch, which includes the office of the Chief Minister.

 

Option D. Chief Justice of Supreme Court: The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of India has a significant role in appointing judges to the Supreme Court and the High Courts, but does not directly appoint lower judiciary officers like First Class Judicial Magistrates. The appointment of magistrates falls under the purview of the High Court of the respective state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sessions judges and magistrates are appointed by the High Court. The Governor and the Chief Minister, representing the executive branch, are not involved in this process. Similarly, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court's role is primarily in appointing higher judiciary members, not First-Class Judicial Magistrates.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 7

questions.text: During the trial of a case involving alleged poisoning, a forensic toxicologist is called to present expert testimony. The judge, seeking to clarify specific technical aspects of the testimony, intervenes with questions. According to the Indian legal system, at what stage or stages of the trial can the judge ask questions to the forensic expert?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Any time during the trial

 

In the Indian legal system, a judge has the authority to ask questions at any point during the trial. This includes during the examination-in-chief (when the witness is first introduced and examined by the party that has called them), cross-examination (by the opposing party), and re-examination (by the original party to clarify points after cross-examination).

 

Questions by Judge: The Judge may ask any question, in any form, about any fact. relevant or irrelevant, at any stage of the examination to clear up doubts. The Court is also empowered to recall and reexamine any witness already examined. if his evidence appears to the Court to be essential to the just decision of the Court (S.165, I.E.A. and S. 311. Cr.P.C.). The witness should not leave the Court without taking permission of the Judge

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. During cross-examination: While judges can ask questions during cross-examination, their authority to ask questions is not limited to this stage.

 

Option B. Examination-in-chief: Similarly, judges are not restricted to asking questions only during the examination-in-chief.

 

Option D. Re-examination: The judge's ability to ask questions also extends beyond the re-examination stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The question aims to highlight the role of a judge in the Indian legal system, especially in the context of forensic cases. Understanding that a judge can ask questions at any stage of the trial underscores their active role in clarifying evidence and ensuring the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the judicial process, particularly when it involves complex forensic testimony.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 15

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a fractured mandible. He reports being assaulted during a fight. The suspect is identified, and the police are considering their next steps. In the context of the Indian legal system, what action can the police legally take against the individual who allegedly caused the fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrest without warrant

 

Option B:

 

COGNISABLE OFFENCE -It is an offence in which a police officer can arrest a person without warrant from the magistrate, e.g., rape, murder, dowry death, ragging, death due to rash or negligent act, etc. 

 

In non-cognizable offences, a warrant is required to arrest  the accused.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arrest with warrant: This option is generally applicable in non-cognizable offenses, which are less serious crimes.

 

Option C. Declare him hostile: Declaring someone hostile is related to witness testimony in court, not an action taken by police during an arrest.

 

Option D. Put him in mental asylum: This option is not a legal action for the police in the case of assault. Mental health evaluations and subsequent actions would require appropriate legal and medical procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, under certain conditions the police have the authority to arrest an individual without a warrant. This includes cases of cognizable offenses, where the police are allowed to arrest without a warrant based on the nature and seriousness of the offense. Breaking someone's mandible in a fight is likely to be considered a cognizable offense, as it involves causing grievous bodily harm, thus allowing the police to arrest the perpetrator without a warrant.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 8

questions.text: In a legal case involving a medical malpractice claim, the court requires specific documents and evidence from the hospital where the incident occurred, the court issues a ‘Duces tecum’ to the Hospital. What does ‘Duces tecum’ refer to in legal proceedings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Summon

 

'Duces tecum' is a legal term used to denote a type of summons. (This term is generally not used in India)

 

Some important Pointers related to Summon –

 

  • Sections 61 to 69 Cr.P.C. deal with summons.

  • A subpoena is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a Court of law under penalty, on a particular day, time, and place, for the purpose of giving evidence.

  • It is issued by the Court in writing, in duplicate, signed by the presiding officer of the Court and bears the seal of the Court (S.61, Cr.P.C.).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Panchnama is used in Indian law to refer to a document created by police or authorities, detailing the evidence found at a crime scene, not a request for documents.

 

Option C. Conduct money refers to money paid to a witness for their expenses to attend court.

 

Option D. Hostile witness is a term used for a witness whose testimony is not consistent with the legal expectations of the party that called them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SUBPOENA DUCES TECUM is Subpoena that requires a person to personally present to the court a specified document or property possessed or under the person's control.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 8, 644

questions.text: In a case of suspected homicide, the forensic team has gathered various types of evidence. The legal team is discussing the necessity of combining documentary evidence with oral testimony for the most effective presentation in court. For which of the following types of forensic evidence is it essential to have both documentary and oral evidence in a legal proceeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postmortem report

 

Option B:

 

In legal proceedings, particularly in cases of suspected homicide, the postmortem report serves as critical documentary evidence. It is essential to supplement this report with oral testimony, usually provided by the forensic pathologist who conducted the autopsy. This combination of documentary and oral evidence is necessary to explain the findings, answer questions, and provide clarifications about the cause and manner of death, as well as any other relevant forensic details.

 

Postmortem report is not a public document. Postmortem reports are made only when there is a requisition from the police officer or magistrate. Postmortem report should be given only to the police.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dying declaration is a written or oral statement of a person, who is dying as a result of some unlawful act, relating to the material facts of the cause of death or the circumstances surrounding it. This has been incorporated in Sec. 32 IEA. It must have corroborative evidence to support it before it can be accepted (Sec. 157 IEA).

 

Option C. DNA fingerprinting: This evidence is generally presented in the form of a laboratory report. Oral testimony may be used to explain the findings, but the report itself is often sufficient as evidence.

 

Option D. Chemical examiner report: Similar to DNA fingerprinting, this report presents findings from chemical analyses. While oral explanations can add value, the report can often stand alone as evidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The postmortem report, as a form of documentary evidence, often requires the backing of oral testimony from the forensic expert to provide a comprehensive understanding of the findings.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 23

questions.text: During a trial involving a complex medical issue, various types of witnesses are called to testify. The legal team is considering who among the witnesses is most likely to provide a statement voluntarily, especially when the statement is not prompted by a question. Which type of witness is typically expected to volunteer information in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medical witness

 

Option B:

 

Volunteering of information: Information should not be volunteered beyond that asked for in the question. The answer should also be limited to the expert’s knowledge. Volunteered information is often not well prepared and is liable to cross-examination. As an expert witness, a medical practitioner may volunteer a statement, if he thinks that injustice will result if he fails to make the statement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Eyewitness: Typically provides information based on direct questioning about what they observed.

 

Option C. Hostile witness: A hostile witness is a person who willfully or with motive (bribe/intimidation) conceals part of the truth or tells a lie or gives completely false evidence in a court.

 

Option D. Investigating Officer (IO): Typically provides factual information based on their investigation and is less likely to volunteer additional information beyond the scope of direct questions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A medical witness, such as a physician or forensic expert, often volunteers information during their testimony. This is particularly true in complex medical cases where the witness may provide additional relevant medical or scientific details that go beyond the scope of the direct questions asked. Volunteering such information can help clarify the medical aspects of the case and ensure a thorough understanding by the court.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 17

questions.text: In a recent case at a district hospital, a medical officer is summoned to provide evidence in court regarding a suspicious death. The officer is aware that certain documents can be submitted as exceptions to oral evidence. Which of the following documents, typically involved in forensic investigations, does NOT generally qualify as an exception to oral evidence in court?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Postmortem reports

 

Option A:

 

Postmortem reports are never admissible in court as document alone, they must be accompanied by the oral evidence of concerned Doctor.

 

Oral evidence:

 

  • It includes all statements which are required to be made in court by a witness.

  • It must be direct—it must be evidence of an eyewitness.

  • Oral evidence is more important than documentary evidence, as it permits cross-examination.

  • A medical opinion is subjective and subject to interpretation and further cross questioning. Hence medical opinion in injury report, postmortem report, Age report, Medicolegal certificates etc. are never admissible in court as document alone, they must be accompanied by the oral evidence of concerned Doctor.

 

Explanation:

 

Options B. Dying declaration: It is the exception to the oral evidence while question is asking which is NOT the exception of oral evidence hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Options C. Reports of Fingerprint Bureau: Is the report of government scientific expert and is an exception to the oral evidence hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Options D.Chemical Examiner’s reports: Is the report of government scientific expert and is an exception to the oral evidence hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exception to oral evidence:

 

  1. Dying declaration:

  2. Expert opinions expressed in a book:

  3. Deposition of a medical witness taken in a lower court:

  4. Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding:

  5. Statements by persons who cannot be called as witnesses: e.g. dead, untraceable etc.

  6. Report of certain government scientific experts: Chemical Examiner; Chief Controller of Explosives, Director of Fingerprint Bureau, and Director of a Central Forensic Science Laboratory

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 17

questions.text: A forensic expert at a medical college is requested to attend a court hearing in connection with a high-profile medicolegal case. The expert receives a document compelling their appearance in court. This document is known as Subpoena. What is the nature of this document?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Legal document

 

Option A:

 

Subpoena/Summon: Subpoena is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a court of law, under penalty, on a particular day, time, and place for the purpose of giving evidence.

 

  • Criminal courts have priority over civil courts.

  • If a witness is summoned by two criminal courts on same day, give priority to higher court.

  • If the summons is from two equal courts, give priority to the summon received first.

 

Two types of summons:       

                            

  1. Subpoena ad testificandum: It is the usual standard Summon where the witness has to give oral evidence.                               

  2. Subpoena duces tecum: Only orders the Person to bring the required documents (e.g. books, papers etc..) written in the summon.

 

Sec. 61–69 CrPC deals with summons.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Medico legal document: A subpoena is a legal document, but it’s not a medicolegal document like autopsy reports hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Medical report: A subpoena forces people to show up or hand over documents in legal matters, while a medical report contains a patient’s health info. They have different roles in law and medicine, so this option is wrong.

 

Option D. Record of evidence: A subpoena is not a record of evidence because it is a legal document used to compel the production of evidence or witnesses in a legal proceeding, rather than being the evidence itself, this makes this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A subpoena is a legal document issued by a court, compelling a witness to appear at a specified time and place to provide evidence, under penalty for non-compliance. Governed by Sections 61-69 of the CrPC, it is delivered by a court officer or public servant, with the witness required to acknowledge receipt. Non-attendance may result in damages in civil cases or imprisonment and/or fines in criminal cases. A witness must prioritize attendance at criminal courts over civil courts, and higher courts over lower ones, when summoned simultaneously.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 8

questions.text: A medical officer at a Community Health Center in India is consulted regarding the legal procedures following certain types of deaths. She recalls that according to Indian law, a magistrate inquest is necessary in various specific situations to ascertain the cause and circumstances of death. However, one of the cases listed below typically does not require a magistrate inquest. Identify the exception:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Murder cases

 

Option C:

 

  • Inquest is legal inquiry into cause of death where death is apparently not due to natural causes.

  • In India, in most cases (whether suicide, murder or accident) the inquest is done by police (under section174 Crpc).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Exhumation cases: These cases often necessitate a magistrate inquest, especially when there is suspicion surrounding the original cause of death.

 

Option B. Dowry deaths within 7 years of marriage: A magistrate inquest is typically required in these cases to investigate potential foul play and ensure justice.

 

Options D. Death of a person in police custody: Given the potential for misuse of authority, deaths in police custody warrant a magistrate inquest to ensure a transparent and impartial investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magistrate inquest is done in only three conditions (under section 176 Crpc):

 

  1. Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage

  2. Exhumation- By Executive Magistrate                    

  3. Custodial Deaths- By Judicial Magistrate

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 7

choices.text: Executive magistrate can order for exhumation
Postmortem cannot be done on exhumated body
CrPC 174 is related to enquiry of exhumated body

questions.text: A medical officer at a district hospital in India is consulted regarding a case where an exhumation is being considered. The officer is assessing who has the authority to order an exhumation and the legal provisions surrounding it. Which of the following statements is true regarding exhumation in the context of Indian law and forensic medicine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Executive magistrate can order for exhumation.

 

Option B:

 

Exhumation:

 

  • lt is the legal digging out of an already buried body from grave

  • It should be dine and completed in broad daylight.

  • 6-7 samples of soil preserved

  • Disinfectants /pesticides should not be sprinkled

  • In highly putrefied bodies, Viscera, hair nails and long bones preserve for poisoning analysis.

  • Time limit: In India, the there is no time limit for ordering of the exhumation

  • Done Under 176 CrPC (Magistrate inquest) 

 

Inquest Sections:

 

  • 174 CrPc: Police Inquest - Done in all Inquests other than those specified in 176 Crpc.

  • 176 CrPc: Magistrate Inquest

  • 176 (1) CrPc: a) Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage b) Exhumation Done by Executive Magistrate

  • 176 (1A) CrPc: Custodial Deaths. Done by Judicial Magistrate

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Police can order for exhumation: In India, police do not have the authority to order an exhumation. This power is vested in the magistrate.

 

Option C. Postmortem cannot be done on exhumated body: Incorrect. Postmortem can and often is performed on exhumed bodies to ascertain the cause of death, especially in cases where the initial postmortem was inconclusive or not performed.

 

Option D. CrPC 174 is related to enquiry of exhumated body: Incorrect. Section 174 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) pertains to police inquests in cases of unnatural deaths, but it does not specifically relate to exhumation or postmortem of exhumed bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the authority to order an exhumation typically rests with an executive magistrate. Exhumation, which involves the digging up of a buried body, is usually ordered for further investigation/ postmortem, when there are doubts about the cause of death or suspicions of foul play.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 132

questions.text: A forensic expert in a medical college is involved in a case where an exhumation is necessary. The team is planning the procedure and discussing the optimal timing for the exhumation. The expert emphasizes the importance of privacy and the need for natural light during the process. What is the preferred time for conducting an exhumation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early morning

 

Explanation:

 

Exhumation should preferably be carried out during early morning hours before the cemetery is open to the public so that there remains some degree of privacy and the whole process of digging and autopsy can satisfactorily be completed during the natural light.

 

Some important Pointers on Exhumation:

 

  1. lt is the legal digging out of an already buried body from grave

  2. Objectives of exhumation

  3. Identification: Confirming the individuality  for  any criminal or civil purpose arising after burial.

    1. Establishing cause of death: When any foul play is  suspected,  exhumation  may  be ordered to determine the cause of death.

    2. Second autopsy: When the first autopsy report is  being challenged or is ambiguous.

  4. The whole procedure should be completed in broad daylight. Hence, it is usually started in morning.

  5. Disinfectants /pesticides should not be sprinkled on the dead body

  6. Time limit: In India, the there is no time limit for for ordering of the exhumation. It can be done at any time after death

  7. Order of Exhumation can be given by an Executive Magistrate (section 176Crpc)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exhumation should preferably be carried out during early morning hours.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 132

questions.text: During a court proceeding involving a medical malpractice case, various types of witnesses are present to provide their testimonies. The judge relies on these testimonies to understand the intricate details of the case. One type of witness has the unique ability to volunteer additional information beyond the specific questions asked, especially when such information is crucial for clarifying medical facts and ensuring justice. Which type of witness is typically permitted to volunteer a statement in court?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medical witness

 

Option B:

 

Volunteering statement: Usually, a witness is not supposed to volunteer his/her statement in a court, unless called for to do so. The witness should only give specific answers to the questions asked rather than volunteering a statement of his own.

 

However, a medical witness can volunteer a statement. It is obvious that the court has no special medical knowledge, and it relies upon the opinion of the medical expert to understand the facts. Only giving specific answers to the questions asked by medical witnesses can sometimes lead to incomplete information and misrepresentation of the facts.

 

Therefore, it is proper for the witness to volunteer a statement if he feels that there is danger of justice being miscarried owing to the court having failed to elicit an important issue.

 

These volunteered statements have the same value as other statements given by the witness in response to questions put to him. The advocates of both the parties have a right to cross-examine such volunteer statements.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Eyewitness - A witness who has seen the event first-hand.

 

Option C. Hostile witness - is a person who willfully or with motive (bribe/intimidation) conceals part of the truth or tells a lie or gives completely false evidence in a court.

 

Option D. Investigating officer - Either a Police officer (not below the rank of senior head constable in all cases of unnatural deaths with the exceptions mentioned under Magistrate inquest) or a Magistrate/ DM or SDM who is qualified and experienced to conduct inquest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Volunteered information is often not well prepared and is liable to cross-examination. As an expert witness, a medical practitioner may volunteer a statement, if he thinks that injustice will result if he fails to make the statement.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 132

questions.text: A forensic expert at a major medical college is involved in an intriguing case. A renowned artist's will has been contested, alleging that the will was signed under duress. The artist had passed away under mysterious circumstances, and now a handwriting expert is needed to authenticate the signature on the will. The expert is summoned to provide testimony in court. Along with the summons, the expert receives a document mentioning a specific sum allocated for his expenses to appear in court, known as "Conduct money." From which court is the summons and conduct money most likely issued?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Civil court

 

Conduct money:

 

  1. Conduct money is a certain amount of money that is paid to the witness towards his expenses for attending the Civil Court.

  2. This amount is paid to the witness while serving the summons.

  3. If the witness thinks that the amount is less according to his status, then he can ask the judge in the Court for an additional amount before giving evidence in the court. However, the final amount is decided by the Judge.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Criminal court: No conduct money is paid at the time of serving the summons for criminal cases. The witness must attend the Court in the interest of justice. The government usually pays Travel Allowance to attend the court, but this is not called conduct money

 

Option C. High Court: A high court deals with both civil and criminal cases and is a higher court of appeal. However, conduct money for a witness is only for civil cases.

 

Option D. Sub magistrate: Handles legal matters at a more local level and is less likely to deal with estate and will disputes, which are typically under the jurisdiction of civil courts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conduct Money is the fee offered or paid to a witness in civil cases at the time of serving the summons to meet the expenses towards attending the court. In criminal cases, no fee is paid to the witness at the time of serving the summons. However, conveyance charges and daily allowance are paid according to the Government rules.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 9
